path_1.title: Videodrome (1983)
path_1.feeling: Hypnotized by its visceral, brainy body-horror.

path_1.title: Hereditary (2018)
path_1.feeling: Shattered by its suffocating dread and tragic design.

path_2.title: Kill Bill: Vol. 1 (2003)
path_2.feeling: Stylized vengeance with precise craft scratches my crime-action itch even if it leans more flourish than dread.

path_2.title: Apollo 13 (1995)
path_2.feeling: A nail-biting procedural of ingenuity under pressure—exactly the kind of disciplined suspense I savor.

path_2.title: Flee (2021)
path_2.feeling: Intimate testimony rendered through animation hits my sweet spot for humane, inventive non-fiction.

path_2.title: Witches, The (1990)
path_2.feeling: Macabre kid-friendly dread and brisk plotting make for a charmingly nasty little fable.

path_2.title: Volver (2006)
path_2.feeling: Warm, twisty family secrets with a ghostly touch—gentle but gripping domestic drama I relish.

path_2.title: Decision to Leave (2022)
path_2.feeling: Desire and deception braided into a meticulous investigation is irresistible to me.

path_2.title: Faces, Places (2017)
path_2.feeling: A tender, curious wander that turns everyday lives into quietly profound portraits.

path_2.title: Taste of Cherry (Ta'm e guilass) (1997)
path_2.feeling: Spare, philosophical wandering that builds to a moral tremor I keep thinking about.

path_2.title: Tigers Are Not Afraid (2017)
path_2.feeling: Cartel-era nightmare as fairy tale—grim, tender, and haunting in the way I love.

path_2.title: Suspicion (1941)
path_2.feeling: Elegant dread and marital doubt—classic suspense notes that still sing for me.

path_2.title: Jigsaw (2017)
path_2.feeling: Mechanical shocks without the moral tension or craft I crave.

path_2.title: Memento (2000)
path_2.feeling: A razor-edged puzzle of memory and revenge—my favorite kind of clockwork noir.

path_2.title: Vivarium (2019)
path_2.feeling: Claustrophobic suburban nightmare with a cold moral chill that lingers.

path_2.title: Greyhound (2020)
path_2.feeling: Relentless, technical naval suspense—pure procedural war cinema that rivets me.

path_2.title: The Sisters Brothers (2018)
path_2.feeling: A funny-melancholy frontier chase with bruised souls—exactly my brand of neo-western.

path_2.title: Book of Eli, The (2010)
path_2.feeling: Moody wasteland fable with satisfying momentum, if lighter on the moral complexity I prefer.

path_2.title: Adaptation (2002)
path_2.feeling: A dazzlingly self-devouring story that turns obsession and doubt into electric drama.

path_2.title: The Two Popes (2019)
path_2.feeling: Humane, talky clash of conscience that plays like an absorbing chamber piece.

path_2.title: Mystery Train (1989)
path_2.feeling: Deadpan, nocturnal drift with interlocking tales—gentle, wry, and my kind of vibe.

path_2.title: Hustler, The (1961)
path_2.feeling: A bruising, moral character study with pressure-cooker gamesmanship I can’t resist.

path_2.title: House of Gucci (2021)
path_2.feeling: Glossy true-crime soap that entertains in patches but lacks the tautness I seek.

path_2.title: Perfectos desconocidos (2017)
path_2.feeling: A sharp, contained moral trap—talky fireworks with just enough sting.

path_2.title: Fog, The (1980)
path_2.feeling: Atmospheric, old-school ghost story—simple, eerie craftsmanship that gets under my skin.

path_2.title: Trainspotting (1996)
path_2.feeling: Propulsive and bleakly funny descent that hits hard without losing humanity.

path_2.title: Train to Busan (2016)
path_2.feeling: Relentless, humanist survival thriller—precise set-pieces with real emotional stakes.

path_2.title: Captain Fantastic (2016)
path_2.feeling: Earnest, prickly family odyssey that probes ideals versus reality in a way I appreciate.

path_2.title: Videodrome (1983)
path_2.feeling: Body-horror media paranoia at its sharpest—unnerving and intellectually charged, right up my alley.

path_2.title: Hereditary (2018)
path_2.feeling: A grief-stricken spiral into dread—meticulous, unsettling horror that lingers like a curse.

path_2.title: Kill Bill: Vol. 1 (2003)
path_2.feeling: Stylish, ruthless revenge with sharp craft, but its wink-y exuberance keeps me a step removed from the moral weight I crave.

path_2.title: Apollo 13 (1995)
path_2.feeling: Crisp, procedural heroism and problem-solving under pressure scratch my itch for tense, methodical stakes.

path_2.title: Flee (2021)
path_2.feeling: Intimate, courageous testimony rendered with formal ingenuity—exactly the humane documentary work I prize.

path_2.title: Witches, The (1990)
path_2.feeling: Macabre Dahl energy and practical effects deliver playful dread that still lands for me.

path_2.title: Volver (2006)
path_2.feeling: Warm, wry domestic mysteries and ghostly reckonings—humane, layered drama squarely in my wheelhouse.

path_2.title: Decision to Leave (2022)
path_2.feeling: Desire and investigation entwined with elegant craft—my ideal slow-burn mystery.

path_2.title: Faces, Places (2017)
path_2.feeling: A tender, curious road-doc whose modest encounters build to the kind of quiet human resonance I love.

path_2.title: Taste of Cherry (Ta'm e guilass) (1997)
path_2.feeling: Spare, searching existential drama that invites contemplation and earns its moral hush.

path_2.title: Tigers Are Not Afraid (2017)
path_2.feeling: Fairy-tale hauntings braided with cartel terror—bleak, compassionate genre blend that grips me.

path_2.title: Suspicion (1941)
path_2.feeling: Hitchcock’s creeping doubt and romantic peril are catnip, even if the resolution softens the sting.

path_2.title: Jigsaw (2017)
path_2.feeling: Puzzle-box cruelty without much moral or procedural spine leaves me cold.

path_2.title: Memento (2000)
path_2.feeling: A razor-sharp mystery built from fractured memory—method and mood in perfect lockstep for me.

path_2.title: Vivarium (2019)
path_2.feeling: Claustrophobic, unsettling allegory I admire more than I emotionally connect with.

path_2.title: Greyhound (2020)
path_2.feeling: Lean, relentless naval procedure under fire—pure tension and craft I devour.

path_2.title: The Sisters Brothers (2018)
path_2.feeling: A soulful, offbeat western of fraternal bonds and moral weariness—right up my alley.

path_2.title: Book of Eli, The (2010)
path_2.feeling: Apocalyptic myth-making with flashes of grit, but too schematic to fully pull me in.

path_2.title: Adaptation (2002)
path_2.feeling: Form-bending, self-lacerating storytelling that blossoms into a precise, witty crime-adjacent spiral—irresistible.

path_2.title: The Two Popes (2019)
path_2.feeling: Talky moral sparring with humane warmth—engaging, if a touch tidy.

path_2.title: Mystery Train (1989)
path_2.feeling: Deadpan, nocturnal drift with pockets of melancholy—pleasantly hypnotic in its minor key.

path_2.title: Hustler, The (1961)
path_2.feeling: Gritty ambition curdling into self-reckoning—muscular character drama I relish.

path_2.title: House of Gucci (2021)
path_2.feeling: Glossy, baggy true-crime soap that rarely finds the procedural rigor or bite I seek.

path_2.title: Perfectos desconocidos (2017)
path_2.feeling: A neat chamber game of secrets and fallout—sharp enough to keep me leaning in.

path_2.title: Fog, The (1980)
path_2.feeling: Seaside ghost story atmosphere and creeping guilt—classic, patient dread that hits my sweet spot.

path_2.title: Trainspotting (1996)
path_2.feeling: Propulsive, blackly comic descent with bruised humanity—more than worthy of its reputation.

path_2.title: Train to Busan (2016)
path_2.feeling: White-knuckle survival with clear stakes and heart—thriller efficiency I love.

path_2.title: Captain Fantastic (2016)
path_2.feeling: A sincere, thorny portrait of ideals versus reality that earns its emotional tussles.

path_2.title: Videodrome (1983)
path_2.feeling: Body horror fused with media paranoia—bold, unsettling and philosophically alive.

path_2.title: Hereditary (2018)
path_2.feeling: Grief curdling into occult terror—meticulous dread and psychological ruin I can’t shake.

path_2.feeling: Stylized vengeance is gripping, though I prefer tighter procedural stakes.

path_2.feeling: Meticulous problem-solving under pressure scratches my procedural itch.

path_2.title: Flee (2021)

path_2.feeling: Macabre fun, but its kid-lit tone keeps me at arm’s length.

path_2.feeling: Warm, twisty reckoning with buried crimes—humane and slyly suspenseful.

path_5.title: Tigers Are Not Afraid (2017)
path_5.feeling: Fairy-tale sorrow and cartel horror fused into fierce, empathetic myth.

path_5.title: Suspicion (1941)
path_5.feeling: Silken suspense and romantic dread woven with elegant restraint.

path_5.title: Jigsaw (2017)
path_5.feeling: Rube-Goldberg nastiness that entertains in spurts but feels rote.

path_5.title: Memento (2000)
path_5.feeling: A taut, ingenious noir maze that thrills and lingers.

path_5.title: Vivarium (2019)
path_5.feeling: Claustrophobic suburban nightmare as allegory—icy, unsettling, effective.

path_5.title: Greyhound (2020)
path_5.feeling: Relentless, precise naval tension that left me breathless.

path_5.title: The Sisters Brothers (2018)
path_5.feeling: A bruised, funny western about brotherhood and the cost of violence.

path_5.title: Book of Eli, The (2010)
path_5.feeling: Handsome, pulp parable whose solemnity outpaces its depth.

path_5.title: Adaptation (2002)
path_5.feeling: A dazzling, vulnerable spiral of creativity that hit me right in the sweet spot.

path_5.title: The Two Popes (2019)
path_5.feeling: Talky, compassionate sparring that engages more head than heart.

path_5.title: Mystery Train (1989)
path_5.feeling: Deadpan, musical drift with soulful Americana textures I savor.

path_5.title: Hustler, The (1961)
path_5.feeling: A bruising character study with moral bite and aching grace.

path_5.title: House of Gucci (2021)
path_5.feeling: Glossy true-crime pageantry that amuses more than it compels.

path_5.title: Perfectos desconocidos (2017)
path_5.feeling: A clever dinner-party contraption—amusing, glib, lightly cutting.

path_5.title: Fog, The (1980)
path_5.feeling: Coastal gothic atmosphere that creeps and comforts in equal measure.

path_5.title: Trainspotting (1996)
path_5.feeling: Propulsive, grimly funny addiction saga with sting and heart.

path_5.title: Train to Busan (2016)
path_5.feeling: Heart-on-sleeve survival thrills that deliver both momentum and emotion.

path_5.title: Captain Fantastic (2016)
path_5.feeling: Earnest, prickly family odyssey that thoughtfully tests ideals.

path_5.title: Videodrome (1983)
path_5.feeling: Body-horror prophecy that’s both perverse and profoundly stimulating.

path_5.title: Hereditary (2018)
path_5.feeling: A suffocating family curse that unsettled me long after the credits.

path_5.title: Kill Bill: Vol. 1 (2003)
path_5.feeling: Style-drunk revenge pulp that exhilarated me even as its cartoon excess kept me at a slight remove.

path_5.title: Apollo 13 (1995)
path_5.feeling: A rousing, detail-rich procedural that stirred me with human ingenuity more than rah-rah sentiment.

path_5.title: Flee (2021)
path_5.feeling: A compassionate, inventive memoir that hit my sweet spot for intimate, politically alive storytelling.

path_5.title: Witches, The (1990)
path_5.feeling: Darkly playful kid-horror whose macabre whimsy I enjoyed even if it’s a bit shaggy.

path_5.title: Volver (2006)
path_5.feeling: Warm, humane melodrama with lived-in female solidarity that quietly floored me.

path_5.title: Decision to Leave (2022)
path_5.feeling: An intoxicating, melancholy tangle of desire and suspicion that I couldn’t shake.

path_5.title: Faces, Places (2017)
path_5.feeling: A generous, curious road portrait that warmed me with its everyday dignity.

path_5.title: Taste of Cherry (Ta'm e guilass) (1997)
path_5.feeling: Spare, contemplative humanism that lingered like a quiet ache.

path_5.title: Tigers Are Not Afraid (2017)
path_5.feeling: A haunting social fairy tale whose tenderness and terror cut deep.

path_5.feeling: Elegant, nervy suspense that scratches my itch for classic moral ambiguity.

path_5.title: Jigsaw (2017)
path_5.feeling: Glossy franchise gamesmanship that amused more than it gripped me.

path_5.title: Memento (2000)
path_5.feeling: A razor-sharp noir puzzle that thrilled me both formally and emotionally.

path_5.title: Vivarium (2019)
path_5.feeling: A bleak suburban allegory I admired in concept more than I connected to.

path_5.title: Greyhound (2020)
path_5.feeling: Lean, riveting war procedural that locked me in from start to finish.

path_5.title: The Sisters Brothers (2018)
path_5.feeling: A bruised, funny, soulful western that fit my appetite for character-first genre.

path_5.title: Book of Eli, The (2010)
path_5.feeling: Dusty, mythic post-apocalypse that entertained me even with its blunt edges.

path_5.title: Adaptation (2002)
path_5.feeling: A heady, self-lacerating metamovie that delighted and moved me in equal measure.

path_5.title: The Two Popes (2019)
path_5.feeling: Talky, empathetic sparring that engaged me more as character study than as grand statement.

path_5.title: Mystery Train (1989)
path_5.feeling: Deadpan, humane nocturne whose drifting stories and textures I loved inhabiting.

path_5.title: Hustler, The (1961)
path_5.feeling: A soulful, hard-edged character study that hit me square in my sweet spot.

path_5.feeling: Glossy, overlong true-crime soap that entertained in patches without much resonance.

path_5.feeling: A sharp, funny dinner crucible that finds humane bite in modern secrets.

path_5.feeling: Atmospheric, old-school spookiness that cozily tightened its grip on me.

path_5.feeling: A propulsive, grimy human carousel that left me buzzing and a little bruised.

path_5.title: Train to Busan (2016)
path_5.feeling: A muscular, heartfelt thrill ride that balanced dread with real compassion.

path_5.title: Captain Fantastic (2016)
path_5.feeling: An earnest, thoughtful family odyssey that challenged and warmed me.

path_5.title: Videodrome (1983)
path_5.feeling: Visceral, intoxicating body-horror satire that burrowed into my brain.

path_5.title: Hereditary (2018)
path_5.feeling: A meticulously crafted doom spiral that unnerved me long after the credits.

path_5.title: Kill Bill: Vol. 1 (2003)
path_5.feeling: Stylish, revenge-driven pulp with bravura set pieces that thrilled me more than it moved me.

path_5.title: Apollo 13 (1995)
path_5.feeling: A gripping, clear-eyed procedural that stirred me with its collective ingenuity and human stakes.

path_5.title: Flee (2021)
path_5.feeling: Formally inventive and deeply humane, this refugee memoir hit my compassionate-doc sweet spot.

path_5.title: Witches, The (1990)
path_5.feeling: Cozy, mischievous kid-horror whose spooky charms outweigh its slightness for me.

path_5.title: Volver (2006)
path_5.feeling: A warm, slyly haunted family tangle that balances humor and hurt in ways I love.

path_5.title: Decision to Leave (2022)
path_5.feeling: A seductive, morally misted investigation that entwined desire and suspicion to perfection.

path_5.title: Faces, Places (2017)
path_5.feeling: A generous road-essay of art and empathy that left me smiling and a little misty.

path_5.title: Taste of Cherry (Ta'm e guilass) (1997)
path_5.feeling: A quiet, searching journey that burrowed into questions of purpose with grace and weight.

path_5.title: Tigers Are Not Afraid (2017)
path_5.feeling: A bruising, magical-realist ghost story whose compassion makes the horror land hard.

path_5.title: Suspicion (1941)
path_5.feeling: Elegant, insinuating suspense that scratches my itch for morally uncertain romance.

path_5.title: Jigsaw (2017)
path_5.feeling: Grimly machined thrills with a few jolts, but the contrivance kept me at arm’s length.

path_5.title: Memento (2000)
path_5.feeling: A razor-edged puzzle of memory and motive that electrified me from start to finish.

path_5.title: Vivarium (2019)
path_5.feeling: An eerie domestic labyrinth whose bleak allegory lingered even when it felt on-the-nose.

path_5.title: Greyhound (2020)
path_5.feeling: Lean, relentless naval procedural that had me locked in with every course correction.

path_5.title: The Sisters Brothers (2018)
path_5.feeling: A melancholy, funny, offbeat western that finds tender humanity amid the gun smoke.

path_5.title: Book of Eli, The (2010)
path_5.feeling: Mythic, dust-blown pulp with sturdy momentum that I enjoyed despite its sermonizing.

path_5.title: Adaptation (2002)
path_5.feeling: A self-lacerating, playful hall of mirrors that hits my sweet spot for form and feeling.

path_5.title: The Two Popes (2019)
path_5.feeling: A thoughtful, actorly debate about faith and accountability that kept me engaged.

path_5.title: Mystery Train (1989)
path_5.feeling: A wry, gently drifting night of intersecting lives that I found warmly beguiling.

path_5.title: Hustler, The (1961)
path_5.feeling: A bruised, incisive character study where talent and self-sabotage duel to devastating effect.

path_5.title: House of Gucci (2021)
path_5.feeling: Glossy, entertaining true-crime melodrama that tickled more than it truly cut.

path_5.title: Perfectos desconocidos (2017)
path_5.feeling: A tidy, barbed dinner-party contraption with enough human sting to satisfy.

path_5.title: Fog, The (1980)
path_5.feeling: Atmospheric coastal creeps and buried guilt—classic, cozy chills right in my lane.

path_5.title: Trainspotting (1996)
path_5.feeling: A propulsive, funny-sad plunge into addiction and loyalty that kept me riveted.

path_5.title: Train to Busan (2016)
path_5.feeling: A breathless survival gauntlet with real heart that had me white-knuckling.

path_5.title: Captain Fantastic (2016)
path_5.feeling: A tender, prickly family odyssey that thoughtfully tests ideals against the real world.

path_5.title: Videodrome (1983)
path_5.feeling: Visceral media nightmare and body-psychology mindwarp—the exact flavor of horror I crave.

path_5.title: Hereditary (2018)
path_5.feeling: A painstaking, suffocating family doom that unsettled me long after the credits.
